title: Inquisitor to warden?

replies.body: Based on the whole "Burn nations to uphold law" description, I think "Templar" would probably be more fitting than Inquisitor or Warden.

Warden is not foreboding. You think of a Warden of the Forest or Warden of the Shire; Warden dredges up memory of protectors and defenders, not zealots who actively go out and burn down villages of "infidels." Inquisitor is a name that IS foreboding and ominous, as it brings to mind total and utter lawful good to the point that you would believe those people would slaughter their own families if they believed them to be impure.

Warden implies a guardian of a place or an idea.

Templar is more fitting than either.

From the [PBE post](http://boards.pbe.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/general-pbe-feedback/bhKEmbia-pbe-bugs-feedback-thread-warden-sivir-and-warden-nautilus):

*We’re changing the names of Inquisitor Nautilus and Inquisitor Sivir to Warden Nautilus and Warden Sivir. We want these skins to feel imposing/foreboding when you play them and we think these names capture that fantasy more strongly than the previous ones. Again, sorry this is so last minute.*

As a counter point, 'warden' reminds me of a fat guy who gets shanked in a jail. 'Inquisitior' sounds A) like it's a 'kill you for your own good' type and B) sounds threatening.

Did anyone ask for this name change? Or is this another 'Finales Funkeln' thing?
in french it's purifier sivir/nautilus so I guess it's a random change from the english team of riot
Yeh I like Warden more. Inquisitor has a bit too much religious meaning behind it. Not sure if that should be in LoL. Probably why Riot changed it.

Leona is the avatar of the sun and worships it... Diana the same for the moon.

One is treated like a savoir while the other branded a heretic...

Malz worships the void...

Brand is spirit of nature...

All of the Shadow Isles...

Mother @#$%ing Soraka Starchild

Pretty freaking sure religious meaning is already all up in this game. 

But if you mean that Inquisitor has some specifically christian tones to it... then don't you think that is a bit discriminatory? Are Christian themes not allowed inside the confined of a video game? 

Ideas from all kind of cultures are present in this game, hell we can't show bones out of respect for China, but a name that is related to Christians that lived over 500 years ago is "too much religious meaning"?

Kayle/Morgana is pretty heavily Christian. But also the basic frame of 'eternal battle of 'good' vs 'evil.' ' Most LoL lore is pretty non-specific from which culture it's taken from, or is a mishmash of several ideas. Some are pretty obvious where the main part of the idea came from- Karma- Buddhism,
Nasus/Renekton/Azir/Amumu- Egyptian,
Pantheon/Leona/Diana- Spartan and by extension Greek..)
But they all have their own bit of unique flavor. And most are set in kind of a good lighting (unless it's 'good' vs 'evil' type story, and even then usually there's reasons to side with the one more on the 'evil' end, or reasons the 'good' side isn't exactly black and white.)

The Inquisition is pretty much all bad lighting and generally agreed to be a stain on Christian history. (There's a reason it's called the Dark Ages)

Though KateyKhaos already said that wasn't the reason for the change, I'd still hold it to be a bad idea to use such a bad era of Christianity in such a forward/obvious way in LoL. Too much 'salt.'

For the Chinese 'can't show bones out of respect' part. It's out of respect, but also, if Riot wants LoL to be played in China, they -can't- show bones because China's equivalent of ESRB would ban the game if it showed skulls or exposed bone. So it would be **illegal** to play LoL in China. China's a huge part of online gaming culture, Riot wants to be part of online gaming.

In retrospect though, I probably should have said something closer to- 'too much negative religious context' other than 'too much religious meaning.'

I actually love when they throw in biblical/religious ideas into game lore. I grew up in a heavy Christian environment, though I'm no longer Christian, I still have a lot of religious knowledge and have great respect for believers and the general healthy mental way of living/thinking a good Christian has. So it hits a nice happy part of my childhood to see it used. respectfully, in gaming.
---
**TL;DR**: Should have said Inquisitor has a bit too salt behind it other than 'too much religious meaning.'

Will I still think Inquisitor is the better name.

I can respect what you are saying, and can see things from your view point.

some sadness that you no longer identify as a Christian but I can certainly respect and admire your willingness to at least be real about who you are... in a lot of ways that places you in a better place than many lukewarm Christians.

Sorry if I came off a bit defensive, I'm just tired of it always seeming like every culture is far game to pull from... until it gets to Christianity and then people seem to go out of their way to appear neutral, to the point that they discriminate against.

Anyway, much love dude/dudet, and props on conducting yourself with some class.
Inquisitor brings to mind a religious police force, like the ones that the church used to have. Warden is more of the person whom oversees a prison.
whenever i hear "warden" i think of the one from avatar the last airbender on the boiling rock

I think it was because, Maurders by defintion means a person engaged in banditry. A warden is seen as an authority figure, like a prison warden. So i think its obvious that the 2 sets of skins were suppose to be counter parts to each other ( like the new voli/trundle and eve/twitch skins). Inquisitor however means, a person who is a part of an organization (inquisition) who eliminate people who commit acts of heresy and other anti religion stuff. So inquisitor and marauder don't fit together as warden and marauder, DESPITE inquisitor sounding more coooler.
